good day folks This is Shane Hasty for
the InfroQue Engineering Culture Podcast
Today I'm sitting down with Adam Sandman
Adam welcome back Thank you very much
Shane It's a couple of years since we
had you on talking about quality and
testing and the trends at that stage was
generative AI was brand new and we were
talking about what's the implication of
that going to be in testing Well we're
two years down the stream What's changed
Well I think we've seen the I guess the
power of of generative AI and I think
we've also seen some of maybe the limits
and constraints We've also seen AI
evolve in ways that maybe we didn't
expect I think two years ago we saw a
large amount of excitement around the
ability to generate things generate
content whether that's code whether that
was blogs whether it was documentation
all things that really I think have
improved the productivity of software
and say software engineering or software
production Some of it's the coding some
of it was the documentation
But I think we've also seen some new use
cases come along which people didn't
expect around you know the new agentic
AI is the new uh the buzzword of the day
but the ability for the AI to actually
start to operate applications and
provide qualitative feedback on things
it was seeing using vision those are
things that I don't think were necessary
forecast from a large language model we
sort of assumed it was more generation
as opposed to more insight I also felt
like we might be further along in some
ways in content generation than we have
done and I think the additional use
cases that everyone gravitated towards
chat bots and coding assistance and blog
writing haven't evolved massively in two
years It's sort of been the same It's
been more rappers around the more
functionality to make it more usable
maybe make it more convenient for people
and people I think have been trying to
map you human and computers together So
in the non-development world whereas
people thought we just have you machines
would write everything people now have
services where it's a human and a
computer doing it together with feedback
So I think what's sh to think is that
we're understanding it better how AI can
help us but we're also finding new ways
to use AI that weren't predicted The
other thing I think that's very
interesting is the cost scaling is very
different than I think we thought We
assume that the primary use case would
be generation of content which a large
language model does quite inexpensively
once it's expensively trained and built
We're now seeing use cases around what's
called chain of thought and workflows
where the inference the computing power
needed to run to actually query the
model in these different ways is
incredibly expensive And so we're
starting to see the limits cost on some
of these ideas that people have So in
some cases where we talk about testing
some of these LM used for testing in
certain ways can be more expensive than
a human tester right now which I didn't
think I would have thought two years ago
So let's dig into the testing because
that's the field that you are an expert
in Thank you
How is the generative AI the large
language models how are they supporting
testing today and what's the implication
of that on testing of software products
Right And and I was I say we we believe
it's quality Testing is a function of
quality And I think if if you testing is
activity quality should be the outcome
So that's my little soap box I just want
to mention that And I know you have info
Q I think Q for quality always I think
where it's being used today for testing
is first of all the developer level A
lot of developers I know are using AI to
generate things that they don't like
doing So for example unit tests We know
that unit tests are horrible I I'm I'm a
developer by trade I used to write code
in C# and Java and still do my know I
may be the CEO but no one when they're
not looking I still dabble in the code
and have fun with it but I hate writing
unit tests Everyone does and we know
it's really powerful We know it's if you
look at the testing pyramid it's the
classic best way to get coverage cheaply
and reliably with the lowest maintenance
and yet we still do a horrible job of it
So we've been using you know a lot of
our clients use AI to do a lot of the
hard work of unit testing particularly
input parameter you know variation if I
want to test this function with a
thousand different parameter
combinations you know that's a horrible
human task developers hate that they
it's the most boring programming work AI
is good at that so you I think that use
case has been well and truly not say
solved but improved with use of AI and
co-pilots and various other assistants
like that other things we've found to be
very good at are test data generation if
you need synthetic test data generating
a thousand phone numbers or usernames
and you can tell it I want these to have
these kind of boundary conditions like
make them very long make them very short
put dollar signs put special characters
whatever It's good for that use case as
well It's also good for some of the
project management testing side of
things So we've seen a lot of success
I've got a a user story using it to give
feedback on that user story I see the
word it is in it lots of times What is
it Is it the customer Is it the screen
making the requirements of the story
better less mistakes and interpretation
by the different people and that
improves quality and then also things
like generating test cases generating
test steps generating automation scripts
Now we start to get I think where some
of the industry is moving in is using it
to improve some of the UI testing and
API testing but particularly UI testing
that's always been the in the testing
world the hardest part to do well
Automated tests of the UI are always
disliked because they break very easily
this the developers want to have the
freedom to change the application that
the business users certainly want the
freedom to be able to improve the user
experience You can destroy your entire
test suite in a in a quarter in a month
very very easily by making large scale
changes for good reason good business
reasons at least And so AI is helping in
some of those cases to make the test
more resilient It's starting to be able
to help all testers take natural
language tests and turn it into
automation And we're heading in that
direction where in theory depending on
who you ask and you know what kind of
application we might be able to have the
AI do some of the testing for you where
it can look at an application and begin
to interpret the business scenario and
interact with it like a human could to
some degree and certainly some of the
models now with their vision
capabilities can actually see the
application and give you real-time early
qualitative feedback like this button is
off the screen this button is a rounded
shape the requirement says it should be
I don't know square or threedimensional
or whatever it is those are things that
we normally have we've missed in
automated testing and a human tester
might not have enough time to capture
those You know a good exploratory tester
might catch them So AI is able to do
some of those tasks now Things that
developers don't like doing things that
testers traditionally didn't like doing
as much And so in theory that's a good
thing if we use that as well as what we
do But if we replace everything with
that the danger is we may miss things So
that's kind of what we're seeing in some
of the AI use cases at least Right So
the term I've been using a lot is that
these tools accelerate us But we're
certainly not saying get rid of the
human in the loop Mm- No In fact AI is
not just building the software from the
spec It's also depending on the
application you're looking at It may be
building the software from its own
learning So for example core set of
software right now is scanning human
conversations with human customers and
using it to improve the workflows
provide feedback There's applications
that self-driving cars is the one people
probably familiar with Those cars learn
by traveling roads learning road signs
We didn't write requirements We didn't
in some ways write code They learned
themselves So if the machine is during
this kind of mission critical highly
sensitive highly safety conscious
functionality that we don't fully
understand You need humans in the loop
almost to a larger degree But I think as
we've talked before the role for the
human and the machine is a little bit
different It's not that we're
necessarily going to be getting us a
user story and writing a ton of code and
maybe a human test it like we may have
done before What the computer does what
the humans do We're shifting some of
that paradigm a little bit you know and
I think people have to be comfortable
with that change in what their role is
what they're good at Computers are
really good at certain tasks LM are good
at certain tasks but as we know they're
very myopic in certain other tasks And
the danger right now is of course in the
rush to cut costs managers or
well-meaning product owners might decide
to try and as you said cut the fuel in

with a quality nightmare and they won't
realize it till it's too late I know
that you do have some studies and some
stats and of course there's the caveat
There are lies there are damn lies and
there are statistics to misquote but
what are some of the numbers that you're
seeing and that you're hearing about
Here's a great great question and first
of all in terms of developers just of
the audience that I know we're talking a
lot to the statistic that was kind of
mind-blowing It came from a a friend of
mine Andrew Palmer from Fujitsu who's
been studying a lot of AI The website we
all know and love Stack Overflow where
we all get you know inspiration how to
write code or solve problems that maybe
have been solved before since November
2022 when chatbt was launched to today
their traffic is down by about 80% Uh
you can see the graphs and other coding
websites are equally impacted It's not
just them So where we as developers got
our content from and maybe cut and paste
maybe edited we're now getting it from
Copilot Amazon Q Gemini we use a lot And
so the question I suppose is is that
code better quality or worse quality
than than copy and paste from Stack
Overflow That's a good question But a
separate study which tries to to look
into that a little little deeper from a
company called Planet in Australia they
came up with a study that the volume of
code has gone up 300% So a single
developer can write 300% more code when
using a good or appropriate automation
tool And I'll talk about little bit
about that next because there are some
better benefits and differences in
trying them out But there's a 400%
decrease in the quality of that code So
that the unit test was failing the the
testing team founders made defects going
into the testing than they had you know
18 months earlier when it was purely
coming from humans and you know human
websites and human knowledge So that's
one of the challenges and I've seen this
when doing coding myself If I have built
some integration with a a system that
doesn't have good documentation and if I
was to search on the documentation and
try and find API methods and
documentation I couldn't find it So I
asked ChatgBT and Gemini independently
to generate what sample code would be
And they quite heroically came up with
very well reasonably looking methods
that look the exact format they should
be but they bear no reality to anything
implemented in the app itself You run
them once they don't run So in the olden
world I would have tried to find the
documentation I would have searched
Stack Overflow which I did do actually
Couldn't find the answers I would have
probably had to then find someone who
knew this tool because it's more obscure
and asked for help or I'd give up or I
would have to do a lot of testing myself
to get all the the JSON all the
different data elements But the co-pilot
tools gave me a sample JSON that looked
just plausible because it looked like
all the other packets that did have
documentation So it fit the format it
fit the spec but it was completely bogus
completely made up I noticed that I
think Gemini was less prone to this than
say chat GBT for this use case but other
cases were different So that's where I
think it can be very dangerous and
introduced many quality issues Another
use case that was very interesting
though where I think it really helped us
is we had some SQL and another thing
developers really hate at least I don't
know as a developer I hate performance
right we have code that runs it's
beautiful we spend a lot of time on it
and now it's slow and the client's not
happy if we have to rewrite this thing
and it's it's the worst task cuz it's
not fun it's not exciting it's not a new
user interface it's just taking
something you've done already and
redoing it so what we did is we actually
asked Gemini to rewrite a SQL server SQL
statement and we gave it the parameters
and why it was slow and it did And we we
we had no idea if it was a good SQL or
not Honestly we we didn't have a lot of
DBAs available for this project And then
when we put it through our unit test
harness it was functionally equivalent
So we had good testing So we could test
it And that's the key here is a good
unit test and it was 30% faster in
production and the client was happy And
that was to me was a really good use
case of AI where we didn't have a DBI
and staff There was a singular problem
we had to do on this one store proc So
you to hire someone for one store proc
to learn your application A lot of times
people wouldn't bother They would just
tell the client well it's as optimized
as it can be i.e with our current team
and maybe that would be it So I felt
like that was a really really powerful
use case where because we had really
good automated coverage that the
developers had written and spent the
time to write we had confidence it was
functionally equivalent but now we could
fix the performance issue which is a
more unmeasurable you know less
quantitative well less deterministic
because it depends a lot on the load and
the types of application We ran it
through the production load where we
could see the benefits for that specific
client's use cases For other clients we
hadn't seen a performance issue So
that's why it's hard to format those and
test those Now with AI you could try
five different combinations And I think
we did try multiple It wasn't just the
first one that ran We tried three or
four got three or four answers tried
each one in turn made sure that the ones
we used were all functionally equivalent
from unit tests and then we took the
fastest of the I think the four So to me
that was a really good AI use case and
good stat we had And again leveraging
the tools for what the tools are good at
Right Exactly So trying to write an API
where the docation doesn't exist is just
literally hallucination paradise It's
making it up based on the pattern So if
all the methods have the same pattern
all the JSON has the same pattern I can
make that up too I can assume that the

hard there's a lot of documentation out

amount of ingestable content but I

was very good at being able to

process that knowledge in a really

for this one business problem that we
had
Other example you you mentioned when we

yeah the autonomous testing yeah for

what it did So this was a simple
application we built for testing So it
is simple That's really important to
bear in mind here I'll come back why
that's important in a minute Uh there's
a login page login password login button
You go to a grid with some data It's a

change the genre change something else
save it That's it Very simple
Traditional automate testing tools you

book I think it was Pride and Prejudice

isn't but that's fine We didn't say
there was a login button We didn't say

it was able to log in and do it perform
the tasks and it performs it every time
pretty consistently It's actually quite
amazing to watch The interesting thing
was on the second go round of one of the

the book back to romantic fiction or
whatever it really is I left it at
detective fiction and I when I ran the

It had figured out that the book was
already in the right genre and so it
said I need to change it So that was
fascinating that is that a manual test
Is that is it the passer of fail My test
was wrong So that's where it can be very
interesting what it can do The other
thing we can have it do is log in and
look at the screen and compare
differences simultaneously while doing
this The problem with this is I feel
like is this shows people especially
people who have budgets This is wow I
don't need any testers We'll just have
us do our testing and magic It's you
it's our testing needs there's two to
three problems with this today Unlike a
modern automated testing script which if
you run them you know every click takes
a few milliseconds It takes about 5
seconds to do every operation because
it's doing what's called decision tree
It's not a simple LM It's using a chain
of thought So it goes through every
possible probability And you can even
see in the log what it's doing It's
doing something like hey this is a
screen This screen's got some links I
edit this book Is that an edit Is it is
that the right one Let me try it And you
can see it thinking this is costing
thousands and thousands of tokens maybe
millions of tokens which translates to
actually hundreds of dollars We did a
study and actually will cost you more
than a manual test right now to use this
at scale today Now the compute power
will change But the second problem with
this is this is just a very artificial
simple application You know what are
people testing for real complex business
apps like imagine that was SAP or
Salesforce or uh you know Microsoft
Office or any of the real apps that you
know you're developing you're testing
it's going to have a hard time Now what
we're thinking in the future is going to
be there though to some degree is the
magic will be the spec If we have good
requirements and this application
understands the requirements and the
documentation it has a better chance of
being able to do this But that means we
need to have better requirements better
quality in what we're doing And I think
it's still going to require humans in
there to help guide this So it's almost
like an intern You've got a testing
intern which can do a lot of tasks quite
well but it won't get it right first
time And you train it So I think as
testers and developers a lot of the AI
is going to be a very smart intern that
we have which works with us almost like

mundane tasks that we tend to short

patent recognition some of the things
understanding the why behind why we're
doing
is very important and especially when

analyst you have to have a philosophy

now are learning for themselves and we
as humans have to test are they fit for

for purpose not the software sense which
is if you build a bridge or a house or
something and it's fit for purpose what
we think of that meaning is does it
solve the business need is not just did
they meet the the architect's drawing
but you know you can't actually walk up
the stairs because the stairs are too
steep So a lot of what we as software
professionals have to think about is
we're almost like engineers and
architects and have to look at the human

whether we're developing testing or
being a business analyst What about the

as a developer I can now potentially
well as a software professional let's

professional software engineer role And

My commitment to that was only you know

What's in your crystal ball Oh well it

one users query like an ephemeral

biases the app How do we know So I think
in my crystal ball I feel like the whole

there was no human building that web
